Comment: They've not rigged a single primary in my lifetime, I still can't predict the future, but if your definition of rigging is that you preferred candidate doesn't win then you may be sorely disappointed.  Objectively Biden was a good choice we got more passed then any president since FDR. he was only a bad choice if you don't care about infrastructure, if you don't care about healthcare, if you didn't care about climate change, if you didn't care about workers rights, if you didn't care about trying bust monopolies, if you didn't care about minorities and treating people with dignity. if you don't care about any of those things then why are you here?  If you did care about those things please explain to me how he wasn't a good choice. He wasn't perfect, but no one would be. I would vote for biden happily again if he was younger. I feel like people who claim the democrats aren't good choices, with some exceptions like maybe sinema or Manchin who were already pariahs, have such unrealistic expectations that anything short of an authoritarian wouldn't be good enough for them.
Author: DeadNeko

Author: PandaBearGarage

Comment: > Please don’t act like there’s not well documented evidence of Donna Brazile and wasserman schulz tipping the scales in favor of Hillary in 2016.  I will, because there's not.  Did the people in the Democratic Party leadership, prefer the candidate that was also a longtime party member over the candidate that had never been part of the party before that election? Sure.  Do they actually take any action to influence the result of the race? No.  It's not illegal or improper for people to have preferences, they are people after all. And before you start whining about "Super Delegates", Hillary still wins the primary even if none of them voted. Because she beat Sanders by millions of votes.  >Or how before the South Carolina primary in 2020 when Bernie was in the lead every moderate dem bailed out and endorsed Biden, except Warren, splitting the progressive vote and consolidating the moderate vote for Biden.  So you mean that the majority of Democratic Primary voters, wanted a Moderate candidate and the only route Bernie had was not to win actual majorities in the primary but to slip through by pluralities? Sounds like the majority of primary voters got the candidate they wanted, by all of the moderates dropping out instead of splitting the ticket against each other.
